issues.title: Timing Belt Failure (M20 Engine)
issues.symptoms: Engine won't start, loud slapping noise before failure, visible belt wear or cracking
issues.description: E28s equipped with the M20 engine (528e) use a timing belt that requires regular replacement. The M20 is an interference engine - if the belt fails, pistons will strike valves causing major engine damage. Factory interval is 60,000 miles but many recommend 50,000 miles for safety. The tensioner and water pump should always be replaced at the same time.
fixes: Replace timing belt every 50,000 miles or 4 years (whichever comes first)
Always replace tensioner and water pump during service
Replace front crankshaft seal while accessible
Inspect and replace idler pulleys if showing wear
Consider upgraded tensioner from later models

repairCosts.notes: M30 has timing chain - less common issue. M20 requires belt service.

issues.title: Timing Chain and Guide Wear (M30 Engine)
issues.symptoms: Rattling on startup, chain slap noise, timing drift, poor running
issues.description: The M30 big-six engines (533i, 535i, M5) use timing chains rather than belts. While chains last longer, the plastic chain guides and tensioner pads deteriorate over time, especially in high-mileage examples. Broken guide pieces can clog the oil pickup. The chain itself stretches with age, affecting timing accuracy.
fixes: Replace timing chain guides and tensioner at 150,000+ miles or if noise present
Use updated metal-backed guide rails where available
Replace chain if stretched beyond specification
Always replace tensioner piston seal during service
Inspect oil pan for guide debris during service

repairCosts.notes: M30 timing chain and guides. Less common failure than M20 belt.

issues.title: Rust and Corrosion
issues.symptoms: Bubbling paint, rust holes, soft floor pans, damaged fender lips, deteriorated jack points
issues.description: E28s are extremely rust-prone, particularly in areas with road salt. Critical areas include the front fenders behind the wheels, rocker panels, rear wheel arches, jack points, battery tray, and trunk floor. The windshield frame and A-pillars can also rust from the inside out. Structural rust can compromise safety.
fixes: Comprehensive rust inspection before purchase (check hidden areas)
Treat surface rust immediately before it spreads
Weld in repair panels for structural rust (jack points, floor pans)
Replace fenders if rust is severe (reproduction panels available)
Apply rust prevention to undercarriage (POR-15, Fluid Film)
Keep all drain holes clear to prevent water accumulation

repairCosts.notes: Common on 40+ year old cars. Check floors and fenders.

issues.title: Oil Leaks (M30 Engine)
issues.symptoms: Oil spots under car, burning oil smell, visible oil on engine, low oil level
issues.description: The M30 engine is notorious for oil leaks as gaskets age. Common leak points include the valve cover gasket, oil pan gasket, rear main seal, front crankshaft seal, oil filter housing gasket, and camshaft seal. While often dismissed as 'normal' for old BMWs, these leaks should be addressed to prevent oil starvation and fire risk.
fixes: Replace valve cover gasket with quality BMW or Elring gasket
Oil pan gasket replacement (requires subframe lowering)
Rear main seal replacement (requires transmission removal)
Replace all seals with quality German-made parts
Address leaks promptly - oil on exhaust is a fire hazard

repairCosts.notes: Valve cover and oil pan gaskets common.

issues.title: Electrical System Problems
issues.symptoms: Flickering lights, dead gauges, check control warnings, intermittent accessories, starting issues
issues.description: E28 electrical systems suffer from age-related degradation. Ground points corrode, causing erratic behavior. The instrument cluster uses early electronics that fail over time. The check control panel (OBC) is a common failure point. Window switches, sunroof motors, and the HVAC blower motor all wear out.
fixes: Clean and re-establish all ground points (multiple locations)
Rebuild or replace instrument cluster (capacitor replacement common)
Replace failed check control unit (rebuilds available)
Clean all fuse box connections and replace corroded fuses
Replace worn switches and relays with quality parts
Inspect and repair wiring harness if brittle

repairCosts.notes: Ground connections and relays are common culprits.

issues.title: Suspension Bushing and Component Wear
issues.symptoms: Clunking over bumps, vague steering, uneven tire wear, wandering at speed, poor handling
issues.description: After 35+ years, all rubber suspension components in E28s need replacement. Control arm bushings, thrust arm bushings, subframe mounts, and steering components all deteriorate. The front end uses a complex multi-link design that requires careful attention. Worn bushings severely compromise the refined handling these cars are known for.
fixes: Complete front suspension refresh with quality bushings
Replace control arm and thrust arm bushings (polyurethane available)
Install new subframe mounts
Replace tie rod ends and idler arm
Install new shocks/struts (Bilstein B4 or B6 recommended)
Replace all sway bar bushings and end links
Alignment after any suspension work

repairCosts.notes: Full refresh common at this age.

issues.title: Cooling System Failures
issues.symptoms: Overheating, coolant leaks, temperature gauge fluctuation, heater not working
issues.description: The E28 cooling system components degrade with age. Radiators develop leaks at the plastic end tanks, water pumps fail, and thermostats stick. The auxiliary electric fan and its relay are failure points. Overheating an M30 can crack the head, while M20 head gaskets are vulnerable to overheating damage.
fixes: Replace radiator if original (aluminum upgrade recommended)
New water pump (metal impeller versions preferred)
Replace thermostat (80°C for warmer climates, 88°C standard)
Install new coolant hoses (silicone upgrades available)
Test and replace auxiliary fan and relay if needed
Flush system and use proper BMW coolant

repairCosts.notes: Full system refresh recommended on older cars.

issues.title: Fuel Injection Issues
issues.symptoms: Hard starting, rough idle, hesitation, poor fuel economy, stalling
issues.description: Early E28s use Bosch L-Jetronic fuel injection, while later models use Motronic. Common failures include the airflow meter (AFM), idle control valve (ICV), coolant temperature sensor, and cold start injector. Vacuum leaks from deteriorated hoses cause running problems. Fuel injectors can clog or leak.
fixes: Clean or replace idle control valve (ICV)
Test airflow meter (AFM) and replace if faulty
Replace all vacuum hoses with silicone
New coolant temperature sensor for ECU
Clean fuel injectors (or replace with new/rebuilt)
Check fuel pressure and replace pump/filter if low

repairCosts.notes: L-Jetronic and Motronic systems. AFM and WUR common issues.

guides.title: Complete Suspension Refresh
guides.description: Full front and rear suspension rebuild for the E28's sophisticated multi-link design, addressing 40+ years of bushing deterioration and wear.
steps: Raise vehicle and support on jack stands at all four corners - vehicle must be completely level.
Remove all wheels and photograph suspension geometry for reference.
Soak all suspension fasteners with penetrating oil - E28 bolts are often severely corroded.
Begin with steering components - remove tie rod end nuts (19mm) using tie rod puller.
Remove idler arm mounting bolts and extract idler arm from steering box side.
Remove center drag link if necessary for full steering overhaul.
For front suspension: remove sway bar end link nuts (17mm), then sway bar bracket bolts.
Remove lower control arm pivot bolt (21mm at frame) - may require heat for seized bolts.
Support control arm with jack, remove ball joint from steering knuckle (taper fit).
Remove control arm and press out old bushings using bushing press set.
Press new bushings into control arm - note orientation for eccentric bushings.
Remove thrust arm bolts at both ends and replace bushings similarly.
For struts: mark camber position, remove three 13mm upper mount nuts, remove pinch bolt.
With strut removed, use spring compressor to disassemble and replace mount/bearing.
For rear suspension: support trailing arm with jack before removing bolts.
Remove trailing arm pivot bolt and press new bushing into arm.
Lower rear subframe slightly to access and replace subframe bushings.
Reassemble all components - torque control arm to subframe 57-65 ft-lbs at ride height.
Torque tie rod end nuts to 25-33 ft-lbs, use new cotter pins.
Install wheels and lower vehicle - bounce corners to settle suspension.
Professional alignment is mandatory - E28 alignment is sensitive and requires experience.
tips: E28 suspension bolts are often severely seized after 40 years - budget extra time for removal.
Heat from a propane torch often helps free stuck bolts - be careful near fuel lines.
The E28 uses an idler arm in the steering - don't overlook this wear item.
Polyurethane bushings last longer but transmit more NVH than rubber.
Mark eccentric bolt positions before removal to get close to original alignment.
Consider upgrading to Bilstein HD or Sport shocks while components are accessible.
warnings: E28 ball joints are pressed tapers - never strike the joint directly, use proper puller.
Spring compressors can be lethal if improperly used - follow tool instructions exactly.
Heat-treated fasteners should be replaced with new hardware, not reused.
Rear subframe is heavy - ensure adequate support before loosening mounting bolts.
Never reuse cotter pins - always install new pins after torquing castle nuts.

guides.title: Rust Prevention and Repair
guides.description: Comprehensive guide to identifying, treating, and preventing rust on the E28, covering all known trouble spots from fenders to floor pans.
tools: Angle grinder with cut-off and flap discs
Wire wheel and cup brush for drill
steps: Perform thorough inspection of known E28 rust areas - this determines scope of work.
Key inspection points: rocker panels (tap with screwdriver), jack points, front fender lips, wheel arches, trunk floor, battery tray, windshield frame, door bottoms.
Remove interior carpets and check floor pans from inside - rust often hides under padding.
Check A-pillars at windshield base and behind kick panels - structural rust is critical.
For surface rust: wire brush to bare metal, treat with rust converter, prime and paint.
For rust-through: cut out affected metal at least 1 inch into clean metal all around.
Create cardboard template of cut section, transfer to new sheet metal.
Cut patch to fit with 1/8 inch gap for welding, dress edges smooth.
Use Clecos to temporarily hold patch in position during fit-up.
Tack weld corners, then stitch weld in 1-inch segments, letting each cool.
For large panels (rocker, fender): drill out spot welds on original, fit new panel.
Grind welds smooth and check for warping - planish if needed.
Treat all bare metal and weld areas with weld-through primer.
Apply POR-15 or similar to inaccessible areas and inner surfaces.
Seal all welded joints with automotive seam sealer.
Apply epoxy primer to repaired areas, then high-build primer.
Block sand primer (220-320 grit) until smooth.
Apply Fluid Film to all interior cavities, rocker interiors, and frame rails.
Touch up or full respray as needed to match original finish.
tips: E28s rust from inside out - by the time you see bubbles, damage is extensive underneath.
Jack point rust is structural - a soft jack point means the rocker is compromised.
Battery tray rust is caused by acid - neutralize with baking soda before repair.
The E28 windshield frame rusts from trapped water - check behind trim carefully.
POR-15 must be topcoated - UV exposure causes chalking and failure.
Treat rocker panel interiors with Fluid Film annually after repair.
NOS fenders occasionally appear on eBay - monitor listings for good original panels.
warnings: Always wear a P100 respirator when grinding rust - particles are hazardous.
Check for fuel lines and brake lines before cutting or welding any panels.
Have a fire extinguisher immediately accessible when welding near interior.
Structural rust near suspension mounts is a safety issue - consider professional repair.
Avoid mixing metals (aluminum patches on steel) as this accelerates corrosion.
Never grind or weld galvanized metal without proper ventilation - zinc fumes are toxic.

guides.title: Electrical System Restoration
guides.description: Complete electrical system overhaul addressing the E28's aging wiring, corroded grounds, failing gauges, and deteriorated switches.
steps: Disconnect battery and let system discharge for 10 minutes.
Begin with ground point restoration - locate all chassis grounds (multiple locations).
E28 grounds: engine to firewall, battery to chassis, instrument cluster ground, tail light grounds.
Remove each ground connection, wire brush contact surface to bare metal.
Sand ring terminal or replace with new, apply dielectric grease, torque securely.
Clean fuse box contacts with contact cleaner - spray each socket, insert/remove fuses.
Inspect all fuses for corrosion or heat damage - replace suspect fuses.
Remove and test all relays - clean relay socket contacts thoroughly.
Replace main relay and fuel pump relay if original - common failure items.
For instrument cluster repair: remove cluster (4 screws), disconnect all connectors.
Open cluster housing and inspect circuit board for cracked solder joints.
Re-solder any cracked joints, especially around voltage regulator and gauge connections.
Replace electrolytic capacitors if gauges are erratic - match values exactly.
Clean all cluster connector pins with contact cleaner before reinstallation.
Test headlight switch operation - replace if contacts are worn or burnt.
Inspect wiring harness for brittle insulation - common behind dashboard and in engine bay.
Wrap damaged harness sections with quality electrical tape or wire loom.
Reconnect battery and test all systems systematically.
Drive test: verify all lights, signals, wipers, gauges, and accessories function.
tips: E28 electrical issues are usually ground-related - always check grounds first.
The check control unit (OBC) often fails - rebuilders can repair these.
Dim headlights are often caused by corroded headlight switch contacts.
The fuel pump relay is a common no-start culprit - carry a spare.
Green corrosion on copper = moisture intrusion - find and fix the water leak.
Don't overlook the engine ground strap - it's critical and often forgotten.
warnings: Always disconnect battery before electrical work - E28 wiring can short easily.
Never probe SRS (airbag) wiring if equipped - risk of deployment.
Dielectric grease on contacts only, not inside connectors - it insulates, not conducts.
Replace fuses with correct amperage only - higher amperage can cause fires.
Brittle wiring is a fire hazard - repair or replace deteriorated sections.

guides.title: Interior Restoration
guides.description: Complete interior refresh addressing the E28's common deterioration issues including cracked dashboards, worn leather, sagging headliners, and deteriorated trim.
steps: Document everything with photos before disassembly - helps with reassembly.
Remove seats (4 bolts each) and all carpeting to access and clean floor pans.
For dashboard restoration: remove dashboard completely if cracked beyond repair.
Option 1: Install dashboard cover/cap over original for clean appearance.
Option 2: Remove and recover original with flocked vinyl for authentic look.
For headliner: remove sun visors, dome light, A-pillar trim, grab handles, and rear trim.
Remove headliner board through rear door opening - flex carefully.
Strip all old fabric and deteriorated foam backing with scraper and wire brush.
Apply adhesive spray in sections, press new fabric starting from center.
Work outward stretching fabric taut - no wrinkles or air pockets.
Cut openings for lights and accessories after adhesive cures.
For leather seats: clean thoroughly with leather cleaner first.
Address cracks and wear with leather filler, sand smooth when dry.
Apply leather dye/refinisher in thin coats - multiple light coats.
Condition all leather after refinishing with quality conditioner.
Replace worn seat foam - driver's bolster typically needs attention.
For door panels: remove and clean or replace fabric inserts.
Re-glue loose vinyl and repair cracked trim pieces.
Replace all window felts and door seals for tight weathersealing.
Clean and detail all interior plastics with appropriate cleaner.
Reinstall all components in reverse order of removal.
tips: E28 dashboards crack severely - caps are easier than full recovery.
Headliner adhesive sets fast in heat - work in cool, shaded conditions.
Match leather dye color carefully - test on hidden area first.
The E28 center console wood trim can be refinished if veneer is intact.
Original seat patterns are available from upholstery suppliers.
Spray leather dye, don't brush - brushing leaves streaks.
warnings: Work in well-ventilated area when using adhesives and dyes.
Headliner adhesive is highly flammable - no sparks or flames nearby.
Dashboard removal requires patience - many hidden fasteners.
Never pull on headliner fabric after positioning - it will stretch and distort.
Test all chemicals on hidden areas first - some plastics react badly.

diyGuides.title: Oil Change
diyGuides.description: Complete guide to oil and filter change on M20 and M30 engines.
steps: Warm the engine for 2-3 minutes to thin the oil.
Raise the front of the car and secure on jack stands.
Locate the oil drain plug on the rear of the oil pan.
Position drain pan and remove the 17mm drain plug.
Allow oil to drain completely - at least 10 minutes for older engines.
Replace the copper crush washer on the drain plug.
Reinstall drain plug and torque to 18 ft-lbs (25 Nm).
Locate the spin-on oil filter on the passenger side of the block (M30) or front of block (M20).
Using the oil filter wrench, remove the old filter - oil will drip.
Apply a thin film of fresh oil to the new filter's rubber gasket.
Thread the new filter on by hand until the gasket contacts, then tighten 3/4 turn more.
Lower the car and add 5.5 quarts (M30) or 4.5 quarts (M20) of 15W-40 or 20W-50 oil.
Start engine and check for leaks at drain plug and filter.
Let engine idle for 30 seconds, then shut off and check level after 2 minutes.
tips: Classic M30 and M20 engines run best on conventional or high-zinc oil.
Many E28 owners prefer 15W-40 diesel-rated oils for the higher zinc content.
Check for oil leaks from the valve cover gasket while you're under the hood.

diyGuides.title: Brake Pad Replacement
diyGuides.description: Front and rear brake pad replacement with rotor inspection.
tools: 13mm socket or wrench for caliper bolts
steps: Loosen lug bolts while the car is on the ground.
Raise the car and support on jack stands, then remove wheel.
The E28 uses ATE sliding calipers - locate the two 13mm caliper bolts on the rear of the caliper bracket.
Remove the caliper bolts and lift the caliper off the rotor.
Support the caliper with wire or bungee - never let it hang by the brake hose.
Slide the old pads out of the caliper bracket.
Inspect the rotor for scoring, cracks, or wear past the minimum thickness.
Clean the pad contact areas in the bracket with a wire brush.
Use a C-clamp to slowly compress the caliper piston back into its bore.
Apply brake grease to the pad backing plate edges and any anti-rattle clips.
Install new pads into the bracket - anti-squeal shims go against the piston.
Reinstall caliper and torque bolts to 58-72 ft-lbs (79-98 Nm) for front, 42-48 ft-lbs (57-65 Nm) for rear.
Reinstall wheel and torque lug bolts to 80 ft-lbs (108 Nm).
Pump brake pedal several times before driving to seat the pads.
tips: E28 front rotors are directional on some models - ensure correct side.
The parking brake on E28 is cable-actuated drum inside the rear rotors.
Bleed brakes if pedal feels soft after compressing pistons.

diyGuides.title: Valve Adjustment (M30)
diyGuides.description: Checking and adjusting valve clearances on the M30 engine.
steps: Ensure the engine is cold - valves expand when hot, affecting clearances.
Remove the 10mm valve cover nuts and lift off the valve cover.
Locate the timing mark on the vibration damper - you'll need to rotate the engine.
Using a 32mm wrench on the crank bolt, rotate the engine clockwise to TDC cylinder 1.
At TDC #1, both cam lobes on cylinder 1 should point up and away from the rocker arms.
Using feeler gauges, check intake valve clearance: 0.30mm (0.012in) cold.
Check exhaust valve clearance: 0.30mm (0.012in) cold.
To adjust: Loosen the 13mm locknut, turn the adjuster screw with flathead, then retighten locknut.
Recheck clearance after tightening - the locknut can change the setting.
Rotate engine 120° to the next cylinder in firing order (1-5-3-6-2-4).
Repeat measurement and adjustment for all 12 valves.
Clean the valve cover mating surfaces and install new gasket.
Reinstall valve cover and torque nuts to 7 ft-lbs (10 Nm).
tips: The M30 firing order is 1-5-3-6-2-4 - adjust valves in this sequence.
Slight drag on the feeler gauge is correct - not too tight, not too loose.
Mark each valve as you adjust it to keep track of progress.
Listen for ticking after adjustment - slight tick is normal, loud clatter means too loose.

diyGuides.title: Timing Belt Replacement (M20)
diyGuides.description: Step-by-step timing belt, tensioner, and water pump replacement.
steps: Disconnect the negative battery terminal.
Drain the cooling system from the radiator drain cock.
Remove the fan clutch (LEFT-HAND THREAD) and fan shroud.
Remove the accessory drive belts by loosening the alternator and power steering pump.
Remove the four bolts from the water pump pulley.
Remove the upper and lower timing belt covers.
Rotate engine to TDC on cylinder 1 - align timing marks on cam and crank sprockets.
Mark the belt rotation direction if reusing (not recommended).
Loosen the timing belt tensioner and slide the belt off the sprockets.
Remove the water pump (3 bolts) if replacing - clean the mating surface.
Install new water pump with new gasket.
Inspect tensioner pulley and idler - replace if any roughness when spun.
Install the new timing belt, starting at the crankshaft sprocket.
Route belt around tensioner, water pump, then cam sprocket - keep tension on the right side.
Adjust tensioner to achieve proper belt tension (should deflect ~5mm with thumb pressure).
Rotate engine two full revolutions by hand and recheck timing marks.
Reinstall timing covers, water pump pulley, belts, fan, and shroud.
Refill cooling system and bleed air.
tips: The M20 is an interference engine - belt failure will bend valves.
Never rotate the engine backwards with the belt installed.
Always replace the tensioner and water pump when doing the belt.
Consider replacing the front crankshaft seal while you have access.

buyersGuide.overview: The BMW E28 5 Series (1981-1988) represents BMW's executive sedan during the brand's golden age. Larger and more luxurious than the E30, the E28 offered sophisticated engineering with the M30 inline-six engine, independent suspension, and an elegant Claus Luthe design. The range-topping M5 introduced the world to the super-sedan concept. Today, the E28 offers classic BMW character at more accessible prices than the E30, though finding a rust-free example is increasingly challenging. These cars reward owners who appreciate analog driving dynamics, straightforward maintenance, and understated elegance.

variants.name: 528e
variants.description: Economy-focused model with the 2.7L M20 'eta' engine producing 121 hp. Prioritizes fuel economy over performance. Can be upgraded to 'i' spec with intake/exhaust work.

variants.name: 533i
variants.description: Early big-six model with the 3.2L M30B32 producing 181 hp. Replaced by the 535i but shares most components.

variants.name: 535i / 535is
variants.description: The sweet spot of the range with the 3.4L M30B34 producing 182-208 hp. Excellent balance of performance and reliability. The 'is' adds sport suspension and limited-slip differential.

variants.name: M5
variants.description: The original super-sedan with the hand-built S38 3.5L inline-six producing 256 hp. Only 1,239 sold in North America. Appreciating classic with motorsport DNA.

variants.name: 524td
variants.description: Turbodiesel variant with the M21 2.4L engine. Rare in North America. Unique character but parts availability is limited.

items.detail: The E28's primary rust area. Inspect carefully along the entire length, especially around jacking points. Poke with a screwdriver.
Check behind the headlights and around the wheel arches. Bubbling paint indicates rust starting underneath.
Pull back carpets and inspect driver and passenger floors. Check under the rear seat as well.
Remove trunk mat and check the entire floor including spare tire well. Battery acid damage is common.
Check from under the hood for cracks or rust around the strut mounting points. Structural concern.
528e uses the M20 timing belt engine - requires replacement every 50,000 miles.
535i uses the M30 with a timing chain. Listen for chain rattle on startup - indicates tensioner or guide wear.
M30 engines commonly leak from valve cover, oil pan, and rear main seal. Check underneath for drips.
Check for coolant leaks from water pump, hoses, and heater core. M30 engines run hot if cooling system is neglected.
Test all gears. Getrag 260 5-speed is robust. Check for grinding in 2nd gear.
Check for worn bushings by grasping the wheel and rocking. Clunking indicates replacement needed.
Worn bushings cause vague rear end handling. Inspect for cracking or deterioration.
Early cars have a steering box, later cars have a rack. Check for play and leaks.
Bounce each corner - should settle in one bounce. Leaking shocks need replacement.
Check if the service indicator (SI) board functions properly. These are often bypassed.
Verify all gauges work properly. Check for dead pixels on digital displays if equipped.
Test all windows and sunroof. Motors and switches commonly fail with age.
Check heater and A/C operation. Climate control panels can fail.

project.description: Rusty or non-running cars needing significant work. Common on East Coast and Midwest cars. Budget 2x purchase for restoration.

driver.description: Running and driving with cosmetic flaws or deferred maintenance. Good starting point for an enjoyable classic.

excellent.description: Well-maintained 535i/535is examples with good history. Minor flaws acceptable at this level.

concours.description: M5 models or exceptional 535is examples. Fully documented, low miles, original or properly restored.

redFlags: Structural rust in shock towers, subframe mounts, or frame rails
M30 engine with severe oil consumption (burning more than 1 quart per 1,000 miles)
Unknown timing belt history on 528e models
Missing or bypassed emissions equipment (illegal in many states)
Signs of overheating - warped head, blown head gasket
M5 without documentation or at suspiciously low prices
Automatic transmission that slips or shifts harshly
whatToLookFor: Factory air conditioning in working condition
Rust-free southern or western U.S. cars
Original paint and body panels (check VIN stickers)
M5 or 535is for best driving experience
expertTips: The E28 is overshadowed by the E30, making it more affordable while offering more space and comfort
The M30 engine is one of BMW's most reliable - 300,000+ miles is achievable with proper care
535is models are rare and undervalued - the combination of sport suspension and LSD is excellent
Early cars (1982-1984) have more electrical issues than later models
The M5's S38 engine requires more specialized knowledge - factor in maintenance costs
European-spec bumpers and headlights dramatically improve appearance if legal in your area
Parts availability is good through specialists like Pelican Parts and BavAuto
The Getrag 260 5-speed can handle significant power increases for mild engine builds
Check the rear shock mounts - they can crack and separate from the body
Join the E28 community on mye28.com for excellent technical resources
